title: In Star Trek Voyager, did Robert Picardo actually sing opera, or was it just an act? - Quora

response.answer_text: He actually sang and he’s not bad by any stretch of the imagination, just restrained and polite. He sings like someone who’s studied a bit and does it for fun - pitch and rhythm are good, but style, tone, and projection are a bit lacking and his range isn’t fully developed. He sings well enough to carry the scenes when he’s singing so it isn’t anywhere near the kind of awkward-to-watch let down like when actors do a bad job of faking an instrument If you listen to a trained operatic tenor you can hear the clear difference it makes to spend years honing the technique to be able to project over an entire orchestra in a 2000 seat hall and do it musically. In some episodes they enhanced Picardo’s singing to make it sound fuller and more extroverted than it was, but his sound and style are both generally pretty cautious. Here’s an example using the same piece: listen to them one after another then listen to them both a second time Jussi Bjorling  Robert Picardo  Picardo’s no slouch but he doesn’t have the zing, musicality, or diction that trained operatic tenors have. He’s also more of a baritone than a tenor. The piece is in B major, but he sings it down a 3rd in G major because he doesn’t have the range for the actual piece. You can actually hear near at about 1:12 that his voice starts to give out on a high E but he covers it well. If he had a more full operatic sound and handled the cadenza, ending on a high B (or G in his version) after sedating Tuvok it would have been icing on the cake

Picardo is an accomplished singer. While he was at Yale University, he was a member of the Society of Orpheus and Bacchus, the second longest running undergraduate a cappella group in the United States. His singing has also been incorporated into his role in Star Trek: Voyager.
